thread.title: BYU report card: Offense and defense earn A's vs. Wagner
thread.title_full: BYU report card: Offense and defense earn A's vs. Wagner | Deseret News

title: BYU report card: Offense and defense earn A's vs. Wagner
text:
The Cougars didn't have any huge problems in its 70-6 blowout over Wagner College.
Scoreboard BYU WAGNER 0 0 Full box score/Player stats Upcoming Games BYU Football BYU football stats & schedule BYU @ SJ State Spartan Stadium, San Jose Nov. 6, 9:30 p.m. 12 Days 11 Hrs 58 Mins 40 Secs More Coverage Sunday morning quarterback: Stars and stats from the BYU win over Wagner BYU QB Hoge, other backups, receive valuable experience in win over Wagner BYU starts strong, easily sprints past winless Wagner, 70-6 PROVO — In a game that was over well before halftime, BYU had no problems putting away FCS foe Wagner College 70-6 Saturday at LaVell Edwards Stadium.
The Cougars racked up 741 total yards — only 36 shy of the BYU record — and had a 49-point lead at the half. It turned out to be a great way to head into the bye week for BYU. The Cougars don't play another game until Nov. 6.
Here are BYU's grades in its win over Wagner.
Quarterbacks
Tanner Mangum played six series for BYU, completing 12 of 13 passes for 237 yards and three touchdowns. He led BYU to touchdowns on every drive he played and finished with a QBR of 321.6.
Beau Hoge was impressive as the backup, completing 8 of 11 passes for 117 yards. His lone passing touchdown, though, came on a screen to David Kessler in which Kessler ran the final 47 yards to the end zone. Hoge also ran 12 times for 49 yards and a pair of touchdowns.
“I felt prepared for the game, personally,” said Hoge. “Coach (Robert) Anae did a good job preparing me for the week.”
Koy Detmer Jr. completed all three of his passing attempts for 57 yards.
Grade: A
Running backs
Before leaving the game after a minor injury, Algernon Brown rushed for 109 yards and two touchdowns on only six carries — 18.2 yards per attempt. Brown later returned to the game but didn't record a carry.
Francis Bernard was also impressive in running for 54 yards on six carries. Nate Carter, Colby Hansen and Toloa’i Ho Ching combined for 129 yards, padded by Carter’s 70-yarder in the third quarter.
Riley Burt did not play because of an injury sustained against Cincinnati, and he would’ve provided a big boost to the backups. Aside from Brown and Bernard, the running backs weren’t as explosive as hoped.
Grade: A-
Wide receivers
Twelve players caught a pass, which is a season-high for BYU. Mitch Mathews caught three passes for 44 yards and two touchdowns in the first half.
Terenn Houk and Mitchell Juergens each caught two first-half passes and combined for 117 yards. Kessler emerged as the go-to option in the second half, tallying three catches for 78 yards and a touchdown.
Josh Weeks, Trey Dye and Jake Ziolkowski all showed impressive talent in the second half. Overall, the receiving corps combined for 411 yards and four touchdowns.
Grade: A+
Offensive line
The linemen came into the game short-handed, but it didn’t stop them from playing exceptionally well. Despite playing without Ului Lapuaho, Ryker Mathews and Kyle Johnson, the line had its way with Wagner’s undersized front seven for the entire game.
BYU’s quarterbacks weren’t sacked all game, and kudos go to the line for its superb play. Also, the offense recorded its first 300-yard rushing game of the season.
Grade: A
Front seven
In the same week BYU lost starting linebacker Sione Takitaki for the season, its front seven played arguably its best game of the year. Linebacker Fred Warner led the Cougars with four total tackles, 2.5 tackles for loss, two sacks and a quarterback hurry.
Manoa Pikula led the team with six total tackles, and Austin Heder chipped in four. Va’a Niumatalolo recorded his first career sack in the second half.
Grade: A
